transcript: than anyone else, Prince Vasfli took possession of Pierre's affairs and of Pierre him- self in those early days. From the death of Count Bezukhov he did not let go his hold of the lad. He had the air of a man oppressed by business, weary and suffering, who yet would not, for pity's sake, leave this helpless youth who, after all, was the son of his old friend and the possessor of such enormous wealth, to the caprice of fate and the designs of rogues. Dur- ing the few days he spent in Moscow
